Definition: Given reviews from Amazon, you must classify them as either Negative or Positive based on their content.

Positive Examples.input: I've read this book with much expectation, it was very boring all through out the book
Positive Examples.explanation: Review writer does not like the book because it was boring, therefore it is a negative review.

Positive Examples.input: I believe I will be very happy with the camcorder. Its small,light and easy to handle.The LCD is clear and bright.Ease of operation.
Positive Examples.explanation: There are positive words in the review like "very happy", "easy to handle", therefore it is a positive review.

Positive Examples.input: love it...very touch.it's to bad that in the dvd description doesn't mention no subtitles
Positive Examples.explanation: There are positive words in the review like "love it", "very touch", therefore it is classified as positive review. Pay attention that although the reviewer is not happy that it's not mentioned that there are no subtitles, the overall polarity of the review is positive.

Negative Examples.input: It starts off a bit slow, but once the product placement jokes start it takes off.
Negative Examples.explanation: This review is positive review since it says that after product placement joke it becomes interesting.

Negative Examples.input: As good as this book may be, the print quality is so bad that I cannot read it. Zero stars would have been more appropriate.
Negative Examples.explanation: This is a negative review. because the print quality of book is very bad and not readable.

Negative Examples.input: I love it, it's LONG and the connection is secure and it doesn't get hot! It's wonderful!
Negative Examples.explanation: This is a positive review because it says "I love it" and "It's wonderful".

Any storyteller can tell you that there's little point in telling scary stories without proper atmosphere. Scary stories are told at night around campfires or in darkness lit only by a single flashlight. When reading this book of folktales, you lose the advantage of total darkness and the timing and tone of a storyteller's voice. What made up for the lack were the strange and frightening illustrations of Stephen Gammell. This edition of the book replaces those with far tamer illustrations. Reading it now is akin to telling a scary story while sitting poolside at noon with all your buddies, there's very little impact or involvement for the reader.I hope someday that Harper Collins will bring back the illustrations that truly made these stories scary, but until then I cannot recommend this edition.

I had read this book over 30 years ago as a teenager and thought it would be interesting to see how I reacted to it now. It's a fun and easy read, I'll admit that. But I can see why I liked it more as a 14-year-old; the book seems to have been written by a 14-year-old. And the "moral dilemmas" are of the kind you probably dealt with when you first learned what a "moral dilemma" is.And although the copy I read was a paperback from the early 1980's that was in its umpteenth printing, it had a surprising number of typos and major grammatical errors. I guess even back then no one took the book too seriously.

The author's intense focus on the main character's inner thoughts and feelings limits the reader's scope and prevents a broad view of the social environment of the book's setting. It was difficult to sustain an interest in the narrow range of concerns that surface in the exhausting detail flowing from the character's mind.
